heading: knowles gets two thumbs up
subheading: the webmaster gets the call he's been waiting for all his life. the ain't it cool news founder does a guest shot on siskel & ebert. by chris stamper.
author: chris stamper
text: for ain't it cool news founder harry knowles, a television chat with roger ebert about movies was the realization of a childhood fantasy."i've been talking movies with this guy my entire life, but i've never been able to hear back from him before," the 27-year-old webmaster and movie critic said. he said he started watching siskel & ebert as a toddler on his local pbs station after sesame street and the electric company.since the sudden death of gene siskel, the show has used a series of guest hosts as substitutes -- tom shales of the washington post and joel siegel of good morning america. knowles said he was booked on the show, which aired in syndication last week, after he sent ebert a letter about appearing.knowles and ebert reviewed pushing tin, lost and found, election, and the video release of a 1977 grade-b monster movie called mighty peking man."we didn't necessarily have the greatest movies in the world this week," knowles said.right now, buena vista television, which produces siskel & ebert has not booked a return engagement for knowles. but it hasn't ruled one out, either. a new format for the program is still in the works.meanwhile, austin, texas-based knowles is busy trying to launch a one-hour weekly movie show of his own. the ain't it cool news site is now a full-time job for him with reports from 35 to 40 stringers.knowles said his site was originally scorned by the hollywood mainstream, but the siskel & ebert appearance was a sign that its credibility is increasing. "they once thought that any one formed out of the internet instead of traditional journalism was a second class citizen," he said.
